coredata.dc:title: Exploring the third dimension: Volume electron microscopy comes of age
coredata.prism:copyright: Copyright Â© 2014 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.
coredata.dc:creator: Peddie, Christopher J.
Collinson, Lucy M.
coredata.dc:description: AbstractGroundbreaking advances in volume electron microscopy and specimen preparation are enabling the 3-dimensional visualisation of specimens with unprecedented detail, and driving a gratifying resurgence of interest in the ultrastructural examination of cellular systems. Serial section techniques, previously the domain of specialists, are becoming increasingly automated with the development of systems such as the automatic tape-collecting ultramicrotome, and serial blockface and focused ion beam scanning electron microscopes. These changes are rapidly broadening the scope of biomedical studies to which volume electron microscopy techniques can be applied beyond the brain. Further innovations in microscope design are also in the pipeline, which have the potential to enhance the speed and quality of data collection. The recent introduction of integrated light and electron microscopy systems will revolutionise correlative light and volume electron microscopy studies, by enabling the sequential collection of data from light and electron imaging modalities without intermediate specimen manipulation. In doing so, the acquisition of comprehensive functional information and direct correlation with ultrastructural details within a 3-dimensional reference space will become routine. The prospects for volume electron microscopy are therefore bright, and the stage is set for a challenging and exciting future.

FIB SEM

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Examples of volume EM data from ânon-brainâ specimens. Serial Block Face SEM data showing (A) B cells containing 200nm beads (Thaunat et al., 2012) and (B) zebrafish embryo blood vessels (arrow; Armer et al., 2009). Focused Ion Beam SEM data showing (C) fibroblasts and cancer cells in a 3D matrix (L. Collinson, E. Sahai and A. Schertel) and (D) mouse retinal blood vessels (arrow; Stenzel et al., 2011). Scale bars are estimates as the images are 2D projections of 3D data. Bars: A, Bâ1Î¼m; C, Dâ5Î¼m.

Comparison of lateral (x, y) and axial (z) resolution (slice thickness) for SBF SEM and FIB SEM of non-brain biomedical specimens. Graph directly comparing reported resolution from the studies listed in Table 1. SBF SEM studies (blue) are typically of a lower overall resolution when compared to FIB SEM (red). A grey line indicates isotropic voxel resolution and shows that, to date, few studies have acquired isotropic data, most being biased towards higher lateral resolution. Typical ranges (boxed in colour) are 5â30nm2 lateral resolution and 20â50nm axial resolution for SBF SEM; 3â20nm2 lateral resolution and 3â30nm axial resolution for FIB SEM. A small area of overlap between the two techniques is evident in the range 5â20nm2 lateral resolution and 20â30nm axial resolution. Studies notable for falling outside the typical resolution range are indicated. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)

Comparison of the total calculated volume of data acquired by SBF SEM and FIB SEM of non-brain biomedical specimens. Graph directly comparing the total volumes reported or calculated from the studies listed in Table 2. SBF SEM (blue) is more often used to analyse larger volumes, whereas FIB SEM (red) studies focus on smaller volumes. As the data points cover a very wide range of volumes, the volume range of each graph decreases by a factor of ten from left to right. Typical volume ranges (boxed in colour) are 5000â500,000Î¼m3 for SBF SEM, and 20â100,000Î¼m3 for FIB SEM. An area of overlap is evident in the range 5000â100,000Î¼m3. Studies notable for falling outside the typical volume range are indicated. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
List of studies that report lateral (x, y) and axial (z) resolution for SBF SEM and FIB SEM of non-brain biomedical specimens.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Groundbreaking advances in volume electron microscopy and specimen preparation are enabling the 3-dimensional visualisation of specimens with unprecedented detail, and driving a gratifying resurgence of interest in the ultrastructural examination of cellular systems. Serial section techniques, previously the domain of specialists, are becoming increasingly automated with the development of systems such as the automatic tape-collecting ultramicrotome, and serial blockface and focused ion beam scanning electron microscopes. These changes are rapidly broadening the scope of biomedical studies to which volume electron microscopy techniques can be applied beyond the brain. Further innovations in microscope design are also in the pipeline, which have the potential to enhance the speed and quality of data collection. The recent introduction of integrated light and electron microscopy systems will revolutionise correlative light and volume electron microscopy studies, by enabling the sequential collection of data from light and electron imaging modalities without intermediate specimen manipulation. In doing so, the acquisition of comprehensive functional information and direct correlation with ultrastructural details within a 3-dimensional reference space will become routine. The prospects for volume electron microscopy are therefore bright, and the stage is set for a challenging and exciting future.

ce:keyword.ce:text: correlative light and volume electron microscopy
focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy

ce:section.ce:para: It has been written that electron microscopy (EM) is currently undergoing a revival, with a resurgence of interest in this informative yet complex ultrastructural analysis technique (Krijnse Locker and Schmid, 2013; Kuwajima et al., 2013a; McDonald and Auer, 2006). Despite provocative titles that suggest otherwise (Knott and Genoud, 2013), EM specialists would agree that their own enthusiasm and workload remains undiminished. Indeed, novel technologies are emerging apace, alongside advances in specimen preparation techniques and significant developments in instrumentation.

One area of rapid development is volume electron microscopy (volume EM), a collective term for EM techniques focusing on analysis of âlargeâ volumes (âlargeâ being a relative description in the EM world). Most techniques that fall under the volume EM umbrella were initially developed for examination of the central nervous system (Denk and Horstmann, 2004; Knott et al., 2008; Micheva et al., 2010; Micheva and Smith, 2007), a result of the need to analyse axons and dendrites that span large distances (10â1â10â5m) with sufficient resolution to detect individual synaptic vesicles and densities (10â9m). The associated technical challenge lay in overcoming the âfield of view versus resolutionâ problem, to enable visualisation of a single specimen across different scales, a problem common to most imaging modalities. The use of volume EM in neuroscience has been comprehensively reviewed (Arenkiel and Ehlers, 2009; Briggman and Bock, 2012; Denk et al., 2012; Eisenstein, 2009; Helmstaedter, 2013; Helmstaedter et al., 2008; Kleinfeld et al., 2011; Smith, 2007). Here, we focus on the development and application of these emerging techniques and technologies to biomedical specimens beyond the brain (examples shown in Fig. 1).

Volume EM can be performed using transmission or scanning electron microscopes. Each approach has its own strengths and weaknesses, and the choice is dependant on the required lateral (x, y) and axial (z) resolution, and the size of the structure of interest. Historically, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was the tool of choice for ultrastructural examination of biomedical specimens at sub-nanometer resolution. However, for many cell biology studies structural resolution is actually limited by the deposition of heavy metals onto membranes during sample preparation. In addition, voxel dimensions may only need to be half that of the smallest expected feature of interest (Briggman and Bock, 2012). Advances in scanning electron microscopy (SEM) technology are now driving a paradigm shift in electron imaging. SEMs with field emission electron sources and high efficiency electron detectors can achieve lateral resolutions in the order of 3nm, allowing visualisation of structures such as synaptic vesicles and membranes (De Winter et al., 2009; Knott et al., 2008; Vihinen et al., 2013; Villinger et al., 2012), though resolving individual leaflets of membrane bilayers remains a challenge (Vihinen et al., 2013). The use of low beam energies also limits the interaction volume, enhancing axial resolution (Hennig and Denk, 2007). In this review, volume imaging in both transmission and scanning EMs will be explored, moving from traditional manual techniques, through to the latest systems where aspects of both sample preparation and imaging have been automated.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Serial section electron microscopy and serial section electron tomography
ce:section.ce:para: Serial section TEM (ssTEM; Harris et al., 2006), a highly specialised manual volume EM technique, has traditionally been the method of choice for examining 3D ultrastructure. A number of impressive works have been published in recent decades, and their contribution to our understanding of biological systems is unquestionable (Anderson et al., 2011; Cardona et al., 2010; Hall and Russell, 1991; Harris and Weinberg, 2012; Mishchenko et al., 2010; White et al., 1986). Still used to great effect, the success of ssTEM depends on the skill of the operator, painstakingly collecting and imaging each ultrathin section, since it is of the utmost importance to maintain the continuity of the series. It also relies on no small measure of luck to avoid the accidental loss of sections and generation of artefacts during section collection (such as holes, folds, shrinkage, and stretching) or contrasting (such as precipitation of heavy metal stains). In addition, slight variations in section thickness are often seen during collection of a large series, and these small differences may distort structural integrity in the reconstructed image stack. Despite the difficulty in getting a specimen to the microscope, ssTEM methods do not require much in the way of specialised equipment beyond that common to any basic EM laboratory, and are therefore relatively inexpensive. For those with deeper pockets, larger fields of view can be imaged using a high throughput camera array (Bock et al., 2011).

Another widely used 3D TEM method is electron tomography (ET). Here, a comparatively thick section (200â1000nm) is tilted Â±70 degrees in the path of the electron beam, and a series of images is automatically collected through the tilt range for reconstruction into a 3D tomogram with â¼2nm axial resolution (Barcena and Koster, 2009; Hohmann-Marriott et al., 2009; McEwen and Marko, 2001; Sousa et al., 2009). This process can be repeated across serial sections to increase the volume whilst maintaining high axial resolution. However, serial section ET has significant limitations including the length of time required to generate each tomogram, information lacking in the missing wedge, limited field of view, and the complexity of joining serial section ET datasets (Barcena and Koster, 2009; Soto et al., 1994; Starborg et al., 2008). A slight variation on the theme using a faster sparse tomographic reconstruction technique has also been demonstrated, which increases depth information using a limited number of tilts (Veeraraghavan et al., 2010).

The analysis of large fields of view and large volumes using ssTEM and serial section ET methodologies is therefore possible but complicated, labour intensive, and time-consuming. Recent advances in instrumentation and specimen preparation have resulted in alternative methods that simplify and accelerate the analysis of large volumes (refer to Briggman and Bock (2012) for a detailed schematic). The most straightforward of these are direct extensions of ssTEM methodology, adapted for SEM imaging of serial sections.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Array tomography, and ATUM nÃ©e ATLUM
ce:section.ce:para: Serial section SEM (ssSEM) is increasingly used as an alternative to ssTEM. The term âarray tomographyâ (Micheva et al., 2010; Micheva and Smith, 2007; Wacker and Schroeder, 2013) encompasses a range of techniques where multiple ribbons of serial ultrathin sections are collected on a solid substrate such as glass or silicon, from which images can be collected using both light and electrons. The sample holder does not limit section size, so this technique is particularly well suited to the analysis of large surface areas. Lateral resolution is comparable to other serial section EM methods, with axial resolution limited only by section thickness. In addition, the sections are stored in a stable configuration that can be re-imaged multiple times, and can be manipulated after collection. On-section heavy metal staining can improve signal-to-noise ratios, and multiplexed immunolabelling procedures can be used to gather additional functional information (Nanguneri et al., 2012; Oberti et al., 2011; Wacker and Schroeder, 2013). To date, array tomography has seen little application beyond the nervous system (Horstmann et al., 2012; Kuwajima et al., 2013a, 2013b; Oberti et al., 2011), with the exception of studies such as that of Reichelt et al. (2012), who used 100nm sections to investigate the 3D distribution of viral nucleocapsids and the shape, volume and structure of promyelocytic leukaemia protein cages in varicella-zoster virus infected cells. Although lateral resolution was not reported, it was sufficient to clearly distinguish individual viral capsids.

A different approach to solving the problem of large volume data collection using serial sections resulted in the development of the Automatic Tape-collecting Lathe UltraMicrotome (ATLUM; Blow, 2007; Hayworth et al., 2006), the next generation of which has been renamed Automatic Tape-collecting UltraMicrotome (ATUM; Schalek et al., 2011; Tapia et al., 2012). Serial sections, each as thin as 30nm, are automatically collected onto a carbon-coated tape for later viewing with an SEM. Despite the power of this technique, and widespread reporting (even extending to inclusion in fictional works; âYou donât have the resolution youâd get by peeling the brain with an ATLUMâ¦â, Egan, 2010), it remains firmly entrenched in neuroscience. This may be due in part to the complexity of the method, and also a lack of commercial development of the system. However, this system represents the first step towards automation of ssSEM.

Serial blockface imaging describes volume EM techniques that record image data directly from the surface of a specimen within the chamber of the SEM, adding automation of image acquisition to automation of sectioning. The specimen remains stationary in the lateral plane during cutting and imaging, which improves image stack alignment. Common serial sectioning artefacts including compression and distortion are avoided because the blockface itself is imaged rather than the cut section. Specimen preparation for serial blockface EM does not differ significantly from conventional EM processing (Deerinck et al., 2010; Tapia et al., 2012). It is possible to use âroutinelyâ prepared TEM specimens, but optimal imaging is only achieved with optimal specimen preparation, key to which is the introduction of maximal contrast and conductivity to the specimen by impregnation with multiple layers of heavy metals (Deerinck et al., 2010; Tapia et al., 2012). This is necessary because signal generation relies on backscattered electrons that are emitted more readily from elements of high atomic number such as osmium, lead and uranium. Metal impregnation also helps minimise charging artefacts by increasing conductivity, which can be further enhanced by using conductive epoxy resin for specimen mounting, and applying a final conductive coating to the resin block before imaging (Deerinck et al., 2010).

Serial blockface imaging encompasses two similar, complementary techniques: Serial Blockface SEM (SBF SEM) and Focused Ion Beam SEM (FIB SEM). In both methods, sections are repeatedly removed and discarded from the specimen surface, using either a diamond knife (SBF SEM) or focused gallium ion beam (FIB SEM). Though the destructive nature of the techniques means that sections cannot be revisited, both techniques can achieve higher axial resolution than serial section EM methods with significant gains in speed. These techniques are particularly well suited to imaging brain tissue, which has a high density of membranes and becomes highly conductive when stained, and good contrast between membranes and cytosol. Non-brain specimens can be more challenging, but despite this SBF SEM and FIB SEM are increasingly being applied across a wide range of biomedical fields.

SBF SEM, first described by Denk and Horstmann (2004) and later commercialised (Gatan Inc., Pleasanton, CA), was developed specifically to enable the automation of serial imaging through large volumes. For most biological specimens, the lateral resolution of SBF SEM can reach â¼5nm2, and it is possible to achieve a consistent minimum slice thickness of â¼25nm with optimal specimens (Fig. 2; Table 1). In an elegant study of subcellular organelles by Vihinen et al. (2013), a combination of SBF SEM and ET was used to demonstrate the complex 3D structure of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), highlighting the potential of SBF SEM for application to smaller biological specimens. Here, a dataset with a lateral resolution of 14.3nm2 enabled 3D analysis of specific subregions of ER sheets, whereas a higher lateral resolution of 4.7nm2 was used for structural analysis of ER sheets and tubules. Other studies with high lateral resolutions of 10nm2 have been reported including visualisation of collagen fibrils (Kalson et al., 2013; Starborg et al., 2013), and the detailed and exhaustive reconstruction of neurons within the zebrafish olfactory bulb (Friedrich et al., 2013).

At the other end of the scale, several studies have been conducted that utilise SBF SEM methods at lower resolution (Tables 1 and 2). These include modelling of the 3D structure of cardiomyocyte sarcoplasmic reticulum at 15nm2 lateral resolution, highlighting network complexity (Pinali et al., 2013); 3D reconstruction of individual hepatocyte and endothelial cell nuclei at 20nm2 lateral resolution, revealing nuclear architecture and chromatin arrangement (Rouquette et al., 2009); ultrastructural analysis of newly formed dorsal lateral anastomotic vessels in the zebrafish at 24nm2 lateral resolution (Armer et al., 2009); and reconstruction at almost isotropic 75nm3 voxel resolution of an entire Giardia lamblia trophozoite cell (Schwartz et al., 2012).

The maximum size of specimen that can be examined by SBF SEM is currently limited by the physical constraints of the ultramicrotome to around 800Î¼m2 (a limitation that may soon be overturned; Marx, 2013), but the total volume that can be examined covers a wide range from 1000Î¼m3 (Table 2; a subset of the original image stack, Vihinen et al., 2013; Schwartz et al., 2012) to immense volumes exceeding 1,000,000Î¼m3 (Table 2; Briggman et al., 2011; Helmstaedter et al., 2013). Such flexibility means that a variety of specimens can be studied by SBF SEM, from individual cells to larger structures such as collagen fibrils and liver tissue (Tables 1 and 2). The variation in reported volumes is related to differences in the biological study, and is also a consequence of disparities in instrumentation (Briggman et al., 2011; Helmstaedter et al., 2013). Outliers aside, most non-brain SBF SEM datasets fall into the range of 104Î¼m3 (Fig. 3; Table 2; Lafontant et al., 2013; Mun et al., 2011; Starborg et al., 2013; Thaunat et al., 2012) to 106Î¼m3 (Fig. 3; Table 2; Armer et al., 2009; Briggman et al., 2011; Friedrich et al., 2013; Kalson et al., 2013; Pinali et al., 2013; Rouquette et al., 2009).

The acquisition of data from even larger volumes can be achieved by stitching multiple overlapping images to expand the field of view whilst retaining resolution. For example, in mouse retina, Helmstaedter et al. (2013) collected images at 16.5nm2 lateral and 23nm axial resolution in a 4Ã4 mosaic to generate a volume of over 1,200,000Î¼m3 (equivalent to 8192Ã7072Ã3200 voxels; Fig. 3) from which retinal cell types and connectivity could be mapped, highlighting the importance of complete high resolution 3D data for tracing smaller profiles. Similarly, Briggman et al. (2011) collected images at a matching resolution and achieved an overall volume of 6,300,000Î¼m3 (equivalent to 3584Ã21,658Ã13,000 voxels; Fig. 3) by acquiring a 1Ã7 mosaic of images. At this resolution, it was possible to map direction-selective retinal ganglion cells through the volume, and visualise individual putative synaptic contacts.

Non-brain SBF SEM specimens can be particularly sensitive to electron dose and are susceptible to imaging artefacts that arise from the accumulation of local negative charge, and sectioning artefacts such as diamond knife chatter or incomplete sectioning. Working in variable pressure conditions by introducing either water vapour or nitrogen gas into the SEM chamber can reduce charging. For optimally prepared specimens, working in high vacuum is possible and results in more detailed images, acquired more quickly at reduced pixel dwell times; indeed, a number of instruments are installed on microscopes that only operate in high vacuum conditions. However, high vacuum operation increases electron dose-related artefacts such as image distortion and shift, and sectioning artefacts, even at low accelerating voltages. To overcome these limitations, it was recently shown that in-chamber coating of SBF SEM specimens is possible, and despite limiting overall series length and acquisition speed, this approach successfully eliminated charge, significantly increasing the signal to noise ratio under routine imaging conditions (Titze and Denk, 2013).

Loss or contamination of imaging planes does still occur in SBF SEM. Images may be partially or wholly obscured by fallen sections, debris and charging artefacts, and if unlucky with a particular specimen, the ratio of lost planes can be equivalent to or worse than that of an ultrathin series collected by an experienced ultramicrotomist. In well-aligned datasets, lost planes can occasionally be replaced by interpolation based on the preceding and following planes. However, this is less than ideal, and large areas of debris will often halt automatic image alignment algorithms. An alternative approach is to incorporate an additional debris detection and clearing step into the stack acquisition procedure, whereby the diamond knife is automatically returned across the specimen â¼40nm from the surface if debris is detected (Helmstaedter et al., 2013).

ce:section.ce:section-title: Focused ion beam scanning electron microscopy
ce:section.ce:para: FIB SEM currently offers the highest voxel resolution of automated serial imaging modalities at â¼3nm3 (Fig. 2; Table 1; Bushby et al., 2011; Heymann et al., 2006; Villinger et al., 2012), approaching the resolution of cellular ET, which makes it the reference volume EM technique for high resolution imaging of site-specific areas. The main benefits of FIB SEM over SBF SEM are a significant improvement in axial resolution, maximally â¼3nm, and the ability to target a small region of interest without discarding the rest of the blockface, which is advantageous for subsequent resampling of other regions. FIB SEM specimens are also less sensitive to electron beam induced sectioning artefacts as cutting is achieved by ablation of material from the specimen surface (Knott et al., 2008; Mustafi et al., 2011), and can therefore accept higher electron doses to increase resolution and contrast (Helmstaedter et al., 2008; Knott et al., 2008; Mustafi et al., 2011).

FIB SEM has been utilised in a number of studies to obtain high resolution datasets, some with isotropic voxel dimensions (Table 1). These include the segmentation and reconstruction of cellular components within entire S. cerevisiae yeast cells at isotropic resolution of 3nm3 (Wei et al., 2012); reconstruction of the complex network of membrane extensions in M. xanthus biofilms at 3nm2 lateral resolution and 5nm axial resolution (Remis et al., 2013); modelling of hepatocyte mitochondria at 3nm2 lateral resolution to examine morphology in a mutase-deficient mouse (Murphy et al., 2010); reconstruction of T cells and HIV-1 virions at 3.5nm2 lateral resolution to study host-pathogen interactions (Murphy et al., 2011); and the detailed reconstruction of segments of human pancreatic carcinoid cells at 12.5nm2 lateral resolution and 10nm axial resolution, and at 2.5nm2 lateral resolution and 20nm axial resolution (Villinger et al., 2012).

At the larger end of the spectrum, FIB SEM has been used to study connective tissue structure in the developing cornea at a lateral resolution of 48.5nm2, highlighting extensive ramifications of filopodial processes in the 3D volume (Bushby et al., 2011), and examine fusing endothelial cells in a zebrafish embryo model at a voxel resolution of 56nm3 and 72nm3 (Armer et al., 2009). These examples show that as well as its resolution advantage, FIB SEM can be used for lower resolution examination of large specimens (Figs. 2 and 3; Tables 1 and 2).

Notably, FIB SEM serial imaging has also been used to study fully hydrated frozen specimens, preserved by high pressure freezing, keeping the specimen as close to ânative-stateâ as possible (Studer et al., 2008; Vanhecke et al., 2008; Weston et al., 2009). Schertel et al. (2013) imaged mouse optic nerve and B. subtilis spores with enough natural contrast to distinguish structural features including Golgi cisternae, vesicles and endoplasmic reticulum at a lateral resolution of 7.5nm2, and axial resolution of 15nm.

The volumes analysed using FIB SEM are typically smaller than SBF SEM, and range from <10Î¼m3 to 103Î¼m3 (Fig. 3; Table 2). The majority of studies examine small regions of interest (Fig. 3; Table 2), from â¼20Î¼m3 (Villinger et al., 2012), to 102Î¼m3 (De Winter et al., 2009; Murphy et al., 2010; Schertel et al., 2013), 103Î¼m3 (Kopek et al., 2012; Medeiros et al., 2012; Remis et al., 2013; Wanner et al., 2013), finally extending to â¼3000Î¼m3 (Schneider et al., 2011; Villinger et al., 2012). Notable exceptions are the studies of Bushby et al. (2011; 69,738Î¼m3) and Armer at al. (2009; 394,029Î¼m3 and 1,669,253Î¼m3), which focus on the reconstruction of large tissue volumes or large parts of whole organisms.

The capacity to image at high resolution using FIB SEM comes at the expense of speed, as ion beam milling is much slower than SBF SEM sectioning using a diamond knife. The need for milling consistency also restricts the available field of view (to as little as 20Î¼m2; Knott and Genoud, 2013). In addition, the full automation of ion beam milling over longer timescales is limited due to inaccuracies that arise from small changes in relative electron beam and specimen orientation (Knott and Genoud, 2013; Knott et al., 2008). By monitoring the transmitted beam current, Boergens and Denk (2013) show it is possible to overcome this limitation and achieve consistent slice thickness even when stopping and restarting stack acquisition. Milling at thinner intervals has also been shown to improve volumetric resolution and accuracy (Ritter and Midgley, 2010). Further, in an extension to array tomography methods, Wacker and Schroeder (2013) suggest that it could also be possible to apply FIB SEM to interesting subregions of selected sections from a given array, thereby substantially enhancing depth resolution.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Where is the limit for volume EM: future prospects
ce:section.ce:para: The tools required for high resolution volume EM analysis are now available, and large scale studies are within reach, but some stumbling blocks remain in the path towards 3D EM utopia.

Optimal specimen preparation for volume EM remains a lengthy process, and exhaustive testing of variables is necessary to find the best approach for each sample type. Consideration must be given not only to fixation, contrasting and resin selection, but also to the sensitivity of the final block to the electron beam, which is influenced primarily by specimen composition and conductivity. For example, insulators such as empty areas of resin, sparse or lightly stained tissue, as frequently occur in non-brain specimens, are particularly susceptible to charging artefacts. Adopting a âlow-doseâ imaging regimen, similar to that used in cryo-TEM of frozen-hydrated specimens, may be useful in mitigating these effects. It is also possible that these problems could be circumvented if the embedding resin itself could be made conductive.

Innovative approaches to further increase the volume of information obtainable from SEM technologies are currently being developed. A multibeam SEM prototype designed for large field imaging has been reported (Zeiss; Marx, 2013). The system uses 61 beams for parallel acquisition in a hexagonal array across multiple detectors, with the potential to generate phenomenal quantities of data at high speed. Similarly, a multibeam SEM instrument has been reported that employs 196 âbeamletsâ in a 14Ã14 array to achieve a minimum probe size of â¼1nm (Mohammadi-Gheidari et al., 2010; Mohammadi-Gheidari and Kruit, 2011). Furthermore, a multi-energy deconvolution imaging strategy has been developed, which can record high resolution isotropic datasets by combining sequential image acquisition over increasing electron beam landing energies (and therefore increasing interaction volumes), with deconvolution methods to enhance depth information (FEI Company; Lich et al., 2013). Virtual slicing by deconvolution means that the requirement to cut ultrathin slices becomes a secondary concern as the same information can be obtained computationally from multi-energy images. Serial blockface imaging methods may also be enhanced by the inclusion of automated focus and stigmation adjustments to maintain optimal imaging resolution during stack acquisition over long timeframes (Binding et al., 2013). Finally, Hayworth (2012) describes an elaborate system designed for âmassively parallel FIB SEM imagingâ using a âlosslessâ method to subdivide and section specimens, combined with parallel processing across an array of identical FIB SEM instruments. Parallel processing has also been proposed for ssTEM datasets (Anderson et al., 2009), and could be applied in other EM imaging modalities (Knott and Genoud, 2013).

The on-going development of prototype instruments, evolution of existing instruments, incremental improvements in detector sensitivity and efficiency, and modification of sample preparation and imaging protocols continue to reveal significant untapped potential, and prospective capacity to image much wider fields of view with hitherto unrecognised quality and speed. Yet, even whilst bathed in the golden light of future possibilities, some enigmatic problems remain; the generation of vast quantities of structural information is all well and good, but can we link our findings to direct measures of function, and how do we go about analysing this data?

ce:section.ce:section-title: Correlative and integrated imaging: bridging the gap to functional interpretation
ce:section.ce:para: Correlative light and electron microscopy (CLEM) techniques match functional information with ultrastructure by combining data from light and electron imaging modalities. Predominantly featuring the correlation of fluorescent marker location with subsequent ssTEM analysis, these studies have proven instrumental in further understanding the relationships between molecules and cells. Correlative light and volume EM (CLVEM) extends this concept to understand the function of molecules in situ in tissues and whole organisms, but to date few studies have been reported as the identification of a single point in 3D space between imaging modalities is a significant challenge that becomes increasingly troublesome as specimen size increases (Armer et al., 2009). At present, solutions include orientation from landmarks within the specimen that can be detected in light and electron microscopes, the addition of specific external landmarks prior to resin embedding (Spiegelhalter et al., 2010), or etching around specific regions of interest in the resin block itself (Kolotuev et al., 2010, 2012).

Alternative molecular localisation techniques have been developed to increase localisation accuracy within large volumes. Immunolabelling is generally unsuitable for use on tissues and whole organisms due to the deterioration of membrane morphology caused by permabilisation agents, limited antibody penetration into the sample (for pre-embedding labelling), and the challenge of immunolabelling hundreds or even thousands of sections (for post-embedding labelling). To maintain good tissue ultrastructure and avoid the requirement for antibodies, direct detection of genetically encoded molecular markers is preferable, such as miniSOG, a singlet oxygen generator that produces an electron dense reaction product by photoconversion of diaminobenzidine (Shu et al., 2011), and APEX, an ascorbate peroxidase tag that chemically converts diaminobenzidine, and can be fused to a GFP tag for localisation (Martell et al., 2012).

However, recent work has indicated that molecular localisation need not always depend on the creation of an electron dense reaction product. Several studies have shown that it is possible to preserve a fluorescent signal after processing into resin for EM. This has been demonstrated in a variety of specimens, including viruses and yeast (Kukulski et al., 2011, 2012), mammalian cells (Peddie et al., 2014), C. elegans (Sims and Hardin, 2007; Watanabe et al., 2011), zebrafish (Luby-Phelps et al., 2003; Nixon et al., 2009), Drosophila embryos (Fabrowski et al., 2013) and plants (Bell et al., 2013). Newly developed integrated light and transmission or scanning EMs (Agronskaia et al., 2008; Karreman et al., 2009; Liv et al., 2013; Zonnevylle et al., 2013) are ideal for simultaneous light and electron imaging of these samples, allowing the direct correlation of functional and ultrastructural information. Indeed, we have recently shown that GFP fluorescence within resin-embedded mammalian cells is stable and active under vacuum in the chamber of an integrated light and scanning electron microscope for in situ correlative imaging (Peddie et al., 2014). Thus, the next iteration of correlative imaging on integrated systems should allow fast, accurate 3D analysis of cells, tissues and model organisms expressing cloned fluorophores.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Volume EM data analysis: the next bottleneck?
ce:section.ce:para: It will be obvious to expert readers that there is a fundamental problem in the storage and subsequent analysis of the vast amounts of image data that volume EM techniques generate. In the recent past, a ten gigabyte dataset would have been considered very large. Now, the collection of raw data comprising hundreds of gigabytes in a single overnight run is routine. Extrapolate from a single stack to the data required for a comprehensive study, and add intermediate alignment and reconstruction files, back-ups and montaging to the equation, and it becomes clear that moving, storing and post-processing the data is no longer a trivial process. In addition, the quantities of data postulated to arise from future studies are probably underestimates (Briggman and Bock, 2012; Denk et al., 2012; Helmstaedter, 2013; Knott and Genoud, 2013; Marx, 2013). Strategies must therefore be designed to cope with this deluge of data. Furthermore, downstream image processing, which can be crudely divided into stack alignment, segmentation of features of interest and 3D rendering of models, is now a major bottleneck.

Restoring continuity to the serial image stack is essential for a full understanding of a specimen. For both ssTEM and ssSEM based methods, this involves the overlay and alignment of each image, and is susceptible to serial section artefacts, and rotational errors or image shifts resulting from changes in relative position through the series. Though volume EM techniques such as SBF SEM and FIB SEM record data from a fixed location, the alignment of images through the stack still requires subtle refinement. A number of semi- or fully-automatic alignment methods are freely available (Cardona et al., 2012; Fiala, 2005; Kremer et al., 1996; Kreshuk et al., 2011; Schindelin et al., 2012; Sommer et al., 2011). Recent examples of automated stack processing include as-rigid-as-possible alignment (Saalfeld et al., 2010) and elastic volume reconstruction (Saalfeld et al., 2012). Stack alignment methods that manipulate image data, for example by deformation, are generally undesirable. However, Saalfeld et al. (2012) demonstrate an alignment procedure that compares each section to those within a defined neighbourhood, forward and backward through the stack. In doing so, this method takes into account the shape of a specimen across many sections and produces reconstructed image stacks with significantly less âjitterâ between slices.

Analysis of EM images is normally carried out by specialists with experience in the identification and interpretation of biological features in the complex grayscale world of electrons. However, manual analysis is labour intensive and can be excruciatingly slow. It is widely acknowledged that more automation in the downstream processing pipeline is essential for accelerating segmentation and structural analysis (Briggman and Bock, 2012; Denk et al., 2012; Helmstaedter, 2013; Jain et al., 2010; Knott and Genoud, 2013). Progress has been made in this area, and in the development of more sophisticated tools, but these approaches remain limited to defined structures such as mitochondria (Dietlmeier et al., 2013; Giuly et al., 2012; Lucchi et al., 2012; Mumcuoglu et al., 2012) and synapses (Kreshuk et al., 2011). Some algorithmic and machine-learning methods have recently been reported that attempt automated segmentation of volume EM datasets, each adopting slightly different approaches (Andres et al., 2008, 2012; Jurrus et al., 2009; Kreshuk et al., 2011; Straehle et al., 2011; Ting et al., 2012; Turaga et al., 2010). But, full automation may need undistorted isotropic data (Helmstaedter et al., 2008; Kreshuk et al., 2011), a benchmark achieved in very few studies to date (Fig. 2). A drawback of many automated methods is the need for preliminary seeding of features, or for experience of training data before they are unleashed on actual data (Helmstaedter et al., 2008; Kreshuk et al., 2011). Developing training data, or ground truth, is in itself an extensive process, and such information is often unavailable since it relies on pre-existing knowledge of the specimen. The complex nature of volume EM data commonly means that automatic segmentation methods need extensive manual intervention to remove false positives and other unintended errors. Despite the best intentions of authors and the online sharing of methods and code, many automated analysis methods remain inaccessible to non-specialists, and can be of limited use on data beyond the realm for which they were developed or trained.

Nevertheless, the projected timings for âconnectomicsâ data analysis, such as the 30,000hours needed for dense circuit reconstruction of retina (Helmstaedter, 2013), or the 2283 years required for an individual to reconstruct 1mm3 of mammalian cortex (Knott and Genoud, 2013) highlight the importance of progress in the fast-growing field dedicated to EM image analysis. In the meantime, alternative approaches have included recruitment of âtrainedâ human annotators (Helmstaedter et al., 2013), and so-called âcrowd sourcingâ initiatives, which exploit the online power of citizen science to speed up data analysis (Giuly et al., 2013; Helmstaedter, 2013). Where an attractive faÃ§ade can be developed to present the data (and not forgetting that developing this framework, enabling widespread online access, and subsequent proofreading are additional steps in the process), these initiatives may yet recruit the hundreds of thousands of hours needed to analyse complex datasets (Helmstaedter, 2013).

Volume EM of biomedical specimens can now be accomplished using a range of techniques, from traditional manual ssTEM to array tomography and ATUM, with serial blockface imaging systems offering the ultimate in automation of serial sectioning and imaging at high lateral and axial resolution. Integrated multimodal microscopy solutions represent the next step in pushing forward our understanding of structure and function at the nano scale. No longer limited by primary data acquisition, the most significant bottleneck in the volume EM pipeline is now the post-processing and analysis of data. To date, a universal solution to this problem remains elusive.

Common to most newly emerging techniques it has taken time, and a certain amount of fumbling around in the dark to develop the procedures necessary for consistent, high quality data acquisition. As each of these techniques finds more widespread application, knowledge transfer is beginning to flow, and publications are emerging that provide detailed preparation methods and guidelines for optimal imaging conditions and data post-processing (Bushby et al., 2011; Knott et al., 2011; Starborg et al., 2013). With a greater level of collaboration and crosstalk between imaging scientists, and with commercial partners, the future may see more developments targeted to specific biomedical questions beyond the brain.

Directly comparing findings is currently problematic due to inadequate reporting of dataset parameters such as imaging conditions, and voxel and volume dimensions. Though this partly reflects techniques still in their infancy, we would suggest the routine reporting of x, y resolution, slice number and thickness, dwell time, horizontal frame width at acquisition or of cropped regions, dimensions of volume, and total volume. Indeed, the number of studies that could have been included in this review, particularly with respect to FIB SEM, would have been much higher had all resolution and dimension measurements been reported.

In summary, we now have the capacity to semi-automatically generate structural data at a range of resolutions matched to the research question. Coupled to on-going developments in specimen preparation, instrumentation, and downstream image processing, we could now be entering an era of unprecedented correlation of functional information within an ultrastructural reference space. The future for correlative and integrated volume electron microscopy appears bright, and perhaps more than a little bit grey.
